definition: A rock of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established (e.g. due to alteration or weathering).

label: sedimentary
definition: A group name for rocks of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established.

label: semipelite
definition: A metamorphic rock that has a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

label: semipelitic gneiss
definition: Type of gneiss derived by metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

label: semipelitic granofels/hornfels
definition: Type of micaceous granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

label: semipelitic migmatite
definition: Composite, micaceous silicate metamorphic rock derived from a fine- to medium-grained siliciclastic sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite, and pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

label: semipelitic schist
definition: Type of schist derived by metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

label: serpentinite derived from intrusive rock
definition: Metamorphic rock composed of more than 75% vol. of minerals of the serpentine group, and demonstrably derived from an igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) protolith (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

label: serpentinite derived from volcanic rock
definition: Metamorphic rock composed of more than 75% vol. of minerals of the serpentine group, and demonstrably derived from an igneous extrusive protolith (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

label: shale
definition: A laminated, indurated very fine-grained rock with more than 66% clay-sized minerals; a claystone with fissility. GSWA now discourages the use of 'shale' as it is considered predominantly a textural term. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: shocked target rock
definition: Non-brecciated rocks showing unequivocal effects of shock metamorphism, exclusive of whole rock melting (Osinski et al., 2022).

label: siliceous sinter
definition: The lightweight porous opaline variety of silica, white or nearly white, deposited as an incrustation by precipitation from the waters of geysers and hot springs. The term has been applied loosely to any deposit made by a geyser or hot spring. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: siliciclastic gneiss
definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

label: siliciclastic granofels/hornfels
definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

label: siliciclastic migmatite
definition: Composite silicate metamorphic rock derived from a siliciclastic protolith, pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. Adapted from Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

label: siliciclastic rock
definition: A sedimentary rock that is silicon-bearing (in the form of quartz and silicates) and is composed principally of broken fragments that are derived from pre-existing rocks or minerals and that have been transported some distance from their places of origin, but otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)

label: siliciclastic rock; undivided
definition: A sedimentary rock that is silicon-bearing (in the form of quartz and silicates) and is composed principally of broken fragments that are derived from pre-existing rocks or minerals and that have been transported some distance from their places of origin, but otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

label: siliciclastic schist
definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

label: siliciclastic + lesser carbonate
definition: Siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals and subordinate carbonate rocks/beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

label: silicified meta-igneous felsic rock
definition: An igneous felsic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock, for which an intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith cannot be conclusively identified. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified meta-igneous mafic rock
definition: An igneous mafic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock, for which an intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith cannot be conclusively identified. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified meta-iron formation
definition: An iron formation affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified meta-ultramafic intrusive rock
definition: An ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified meta-ultramafic rock
definition: An ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified metacarbonatite
definition: A metamorphosed carbonatite affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified metachert
definition: A chert affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified metaconglomerate
definition: A metamorphosed conglomerate affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified metafelsic volcanic rock
definition: A felsic igneous volcanic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metarhyolite) cannot be identified. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

label: silicified metagranitic rock
definition: A felsic intrusive rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metasyenite) cannot be identified.

label: silicified metamafic intrusive rock
definition: A mafic intrusive rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metagabbro) cannot be identified.

label: silicified metamafic volcanic rock
definition: A mafic volcanic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metabasalt) cannot be identified.

label: silicified metasiliciclastic rock
definition: A siliciclastic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified metavolcanic or metavolcaniclastic rock
definition: A metamorphosed volcanic or volcaniclastic rock otherwise uncategorized and affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified pelite
definition: A metamorphosed fine-grained siliciclastic rock, otherwise uncategorized, affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified psammite and pelite; interlayered
definition: A succession of sandstone and mudstone beds affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: silicified semipelite
definition: A metamorphosed fine- to medium-grained siliciclastic rock, otherwise uncategorized, affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

label: siltstone
definition: An indurated mud in which silt predominates over clay (clay less than 66%). Siltstone has the grain size and composition of shale but lacks its fine lamination or fissility; it tends to be flaggy, containing hard, durable, generally thin layers, and commonly shows various primary current structures. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: siltstone + sandstone
definition: Siltstone and sandstone beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

label: slate
definition: Ultrafine- or very fine-grained metamorphic rock displaying slaty cleavage, i.e. a type of continuous cleavage in which the individual grains are too small to be seen by the unaided eye. Slate is usually of very low metamorphic grade, although it may also occur under low-grade conditions. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.–195)

label: spessartite
definition: A variety of lamprophyre consisting of phenocrysts of hornblende with or without biotite, olivine or pyroxene in a groundmass of the same minerals plus plagioclase and subordinate alkali feldspar. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 144)

label: spongolite/spicularite
definition: A sediment or rock composed principally of the remains of sponges. A sediment predominantly composed of discrete spicules is termed a spicularite, whereas one predominantly composed of rigid bodied sponges is termed a spongolite. Adapted from Gammon (1978) and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: stromatoporoid dolomite
definition: A dolomite rock distinguished by the presence of stromatoporoids, i.e. extinct sessile, benthic, reef-forming sponges with calcareous skeletons that were especially abundant from the Paleozoic to the Cretaceous periods.

label: stromatoporoid limestone
definition: A limestone distinguished by the presence of stromatoporoids, i.e. extinct sessile, benthic, reef-forming sponges with calcareous skeletons that were especially abundant from the Paleozoic to the Cretaceous periods.

label: sub-bituminous coal
definition: A black coal, intermediate in rank between lignite and bituminous coals or, in some classifications, the equivalent of black lignite. It is distinguished from lignite by higher carbon and lower moisture content. Further classification of sub-bituminous coal is made on the basis of calorific value. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: subarkose
definition: An arenite that does not have enough feldspar to be classed as an arkose, or that is intermediate in composition between arkose and quartzarenite. Subarkose specifically contains 75–95% quartz and chert, and 5–25% unstable materials in which the ratio of feldspar:lithic grains is greater than 1:1. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: sublitharenite
definition: An arenite that is intermediate in composition between a litharenite and a quartzarenite; specifically containing 5–25% rock/lithic grains and a feldspar:lithic ratio less than 1:1. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: suevite
definition: Polymictic impact breccia with particulate matrix containing lithic and mineral clasts in all stages of shock metamorphism including cogenetic impact melt particles, which are in a glassy or crystallized state (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 198).

label: syenite
definition: An intrusive rock consisting mainly of alkali feldspar with subordinate sodic plagioclase, biotite, pyroxene, amphibole and occasional fayalite. Minor quartz or nepheline may also be present. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 145)

label: syenogranite
definition: An optional term for a variety of granite in QAPF field 3a (Fig. 2.4, p. 22) consisting of alkali feldspar with subordinate plagioclase (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 146).

label: tektite
definition: Impact glass formed at terrestrial impact craters from melt ejected ballistically and deposited as aerodynamically shaped bodies in a strewn field outside the continuous ejecta blanket. The size of tektites ranges from the submillimetre range (microtektites, generally found in deep sea sediments) to the subdecimetre range, rarely to decimetres. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  200)

label: tonalite
definition: An intrusive rock consisting essentially of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Now defined modally in QAPF field 5 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 149)

label: tourmaline vein
definition: A rock comprising tourmaline crystals of pegmatitic or hydrothermal origin, as vein-filling material.

label: trachyte
definition: A volcanic rock consisting essentially of alkali feldspar. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field T (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 151). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

label: travertine
definition: Biotically and/or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate (predominantly calcite and aragonite) from spring-fed, heated and/or ambient-temperature waters. The spongy or less compact variety is named tufa. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

label: troctolite
definition: A variety of gabbro composed essentially of highly calcic plagioclase and olivine with little or no pyroxene. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 151)

label: trondhjemite
definition: A leucocratic variety of tonalite consisting essentially of sodic plagioclase and quartz with minor biotite. Orthoclase is characteristically absent and hornblende is rare. May be used as a synonym for plagiogranite and leucocratic tonalite of QAPF field 5 (p. 23). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 152)

label: ultracataclasite
definition: A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes more than 90% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 202).

label: ultramafic gneiss derived from intrusive rock
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

label: ultramafic gneiss; volcanic or undivided
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss derived from an extrusive or related rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

label: ultramafic granofels/hornfels derived from intrusive rock
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main components (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 202). See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

label: ultramafic granofels/hornfels; volcanic or undivided
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from an extrusive or related rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main components (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 202). See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

label: ultramafic intrusive rock
definition: Originally a term for a rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals, e.g. peridotite, dunite. Now defined as a rock with M>90%. Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 21 and p. 153).

label: ultramafic intrusive rock; undivided
definition: A demonstrably ultramafic (M>90%) intrusive rock, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

label: ultramafic schist derived from intrusive rock
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

label: ultramafic schist; volcanic or undivided
definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

label: ultramafic volcanic rock
definition: An igneous volcanic rock composed chiefly of one or more ferromagnesian, dark-coloured minerals in its mode (adapted from Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Originally a term for a rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals, e.g. peridotite, dunite. Now defined as a rock with M greater than 90% (section 2.11.2, p. 28), where M represents the volume modal percentage of mafic and related minerals (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 4 and 153). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

label: ultramafic volcanic rock; undivided
definition: A demonstrably ultramafic igneous volcanic rock, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic breccia
definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments greater than 2 mm in size consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic breccia-sandstone
definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625 – 2 mm) and above, consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic conglomerate
definition: A conglomerate consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic granule/pebble breccia
definition: A breccia composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from granule (2–4 mm) to pebble (4–32 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic mudstone
definition: A mudstone (grain size ranging from silt to clay, i.e. less than 0.0625 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall mafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic rock
definition: A volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with an overall mafic composition, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sandstone
definition: A sandstone (grain size 0.0625 – 2 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sandstone-siltstone
definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625 – 2 mm) to silt (0.0039 – 0.0625 mm) of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion.

label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sediment-matrix breccia
definition: A commonly monomictic breccia of overall ultramafic composition composed of angular, coarse igneous fragments cemented by a fine-grained matrix that is clastic though not necessarily strictly sedimentary in origin. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

label: ultramylonite
definition: Mylonite in which more than 90% of the rock volume has undergone grain-size reduction (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  202); a mylonite with over 90% matrix and less than 10% porphyroclasts (Passchier and Trouw, 2005).

label: unknown lithology
definition: A rock so altered, weathered or of such a fine grain size that an inference on the protolith or origin of the rock cannot be made. Also used to allocate a lithology to sample legacy data where a lithology was not known. The use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Field observation database (WAROX).

label: unknown
definition: A group name for lithologies so altered, weathered or of such a fine grain size that an inference on the protolith or origin of the rock cannot be made. Also used to allocate a lithology to sample legacy data where a lithology was not known. The use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Field observation database (WAROX).

label: vein
definition: A distinct sheet-like body of crystallized minerals within a rock. Veins form when mineral constituents carried by an aqueous solution within the rock mass are deposited through precipitation. The hydraulic flow involved is usually due to hydrothermal circulation. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vein_(geology)).

label: vogesite
definition: A variety of lamprophyre in which amphibole is more abundant than biotite and alkali feldspar is more abundant than plagioclase. Augite is frequently present. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 155)

label: volcanic rock
definition: A rock of igneous volcanic/extrusive origin but commonly too weathered to make further distinctions.

label: igneous volcanic
definition: A group name for rock types of igneous extrusive (or volcanic) origin.

label: websterite
definition: A variety of pyroxenite consisting largely of varying amounts of orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene, with less than 10% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 156).

label: wehrlite
definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock composed of olivine and clinopyroxene often with minor brown hornblende. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 156)

label: xenolith- or inclusion-bearing lithology
definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize mixed lithological types (metamorphosed or not), where the first code represents the host rock lithology and the second code represents the dominant lithology of the xenolith/inclusions.

label: xenolith- or inclusion-bearing
definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize mixed rock types (metamorphosed or not) where one of the component is a xenolith or inclusion.

label: metamorphic: protolith unknown
definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks for which the protolith cannot be identified.
